results.name: a(n) = (2*(-4)^((p-3)/4) + 1)/p, where p is the n-th prime congruent to 3 mod 4.
comment: a(n) is always an integer. If p == 3 (mod 8), then 2*(-4)^((p-3)/4) == 2*4^((p-3)/4) == 2^((p-1)/2) (mod p). 2 is a quadratic nonresidue modulo p so 2^((p-1)/2) == -1 (mod p). If p == 7 (mod 8), then 2*(-4)^((p-3)/4) == -2*4^((p-3)/4) == -2^((p-1)/2) (mod p). 2 is a quadratic residue modulo p so 2^((p-1)/2) == 1 (mod p).
example: The third prime congruent to 3 mod 4 is 11, so a(3) = (2*(-4)^2 + 1)/11 = 33/11 = 3.
